title: How many paying subscribers will "Disney+" have according to Disney in the second quarter of its Fiscal Year 2020?
possible_answers: More than 45.0 million but less than 55.0 million
Disney will not report paying subscriber figures for Disney+
preds: Disney subscriber article noting 50 million subscribers 9 days after Q2 closing as stated below.
Underestimated Disney+'s ability to draw subscribers, but based on the ~8million subscribers for India which was only launched Apr 2, will stick with my initial forecast that it's under 45 million.
The number of subscribers just recently rose above 50m.

https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-plus-streaming-subscriber-count-growth-50-million-2020-4 Disney reported 50M subscribers on April 8, which is DOUBLE what they had reported in February. Some of this growth is obviously spurred on by millions of kids staying home and their parents needing a "virtual baby-sitter" while they work. It should be noted, however, that this number comes in April (after their Q2), meaning forecasters should "backtrack" to what the subscriber count was at the end of April. Regardless, I deem it likely that the reported 50M number was still above 45M 9 days prior to the article above's release. I believe it unlikely that Disney+ subscribers fall from April reporting numbers, so anything below 50M has low odds. I also find it hard to believe that their biggest metric in Disney+ (subscribers) would be omitted. So a 60% chance

initial guess would say 0.5x the domestic launch result of 25M for EU. So say about 12M and then further development of the domestic. So pure guess of 20M more. Don't believe much in not reporting the figures if they have done already. To be followed.
Corona sure helps but on the other hand there are critical responses in Europe with regard to the not very diverse content.

Disney + subscriber nos have been revealed in April (?) to have surpassed 50 million. This includes international markets like India, and people accessing Disney + for free (while being subsidized by someone else - like their ISP).  The final number released on May 12th could be between 50 to 55 million. There is a slight chance that they could beat 55 million (with the last 2 weeks of March 20 showing increasing signups and people were heading into lockdown the world over).  - data release in April 20 could have been to reassure investors after the hammering the stock received in March 20
- investors might enjoy Disney + beating the anchor no that they will now carry till 12th May (i.e. 50 Million)

With the recent launch of Disney+ in Europe and the effects of CoronaVirus forcing people to stay at home Disney+ released preliminary numbers at the beginning of the month with a subscriber count of already surpassing 50 million. Considering that since the launch of Disney+ only 5 months ago it has already racked up 50 million paying subscribers its rate of growth says it should be upwards of 55 million. I don't expect a drop-off anytime soon either as market leader Netflix has over 170 million paying subscribers many of whom pay for multiple streaming services as well. I think it's also important to note that none of the market leading streaming platforms are present in China. Disney as a cooperation has had a strong history with China and although this may not produce direct number growth by may 12th its promising for investors and supporters of the platform.

Disney+ hit 50 million subscribers as of 4/8, and that number will not decline by 5/12 thanks to promotional offers and shelter-in-place requirements. The only question is whether that will increase another 5 million by 5/12. Considering they've almost doubled subscribers from the 28.6M they ended with in Q1, they likely have the momentum to finish the quarter above this mark.

Press reports are that subscribers hit 50m at some point during the period in question, but  a little vague. The reason for a small alloc to the 'will not report' is that it is possible the company may not want to highlight these figures given the potentially unseemly aspect, i.e. company benefitting from COVID . I think that's a very low probability (5%) but it isn't zero.
Not reporting less likely from what I know

Disney+ has already hit 50 million subscribers with the addition of Europe in March. I belive that as more states started shelter in place towards the end of March 2020 that would have been the last push needed to cross the 55 million number.  https://www.bbc.com/news/business-52211207

Adjusted to correct estimate for Fiscal ending on March 31st. The article I originally cite (https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/8/21214236/disney-plus-50-million-subscribers-international-europe-india-netflix) was from April 8th, so probably very close to the EOQ number. If it was over 55 million, they probably would have cited that instead. Previous
0% Less than 35.0 million
0% Between 35.0 million and 45.0 million, inclusive
1% More than 45.0 million but less than 55.0 million
99% 55.0 million or more
0% Disney will not report paying subscriber figures for Disney+

Disney has already hit 50 mil+ subscribers and is quite likely to overshoot the 55 mil mark by a margin, by the time the results of its second quarters are announced. Disney will almost definitely announce the figures as Disney+ is one of the main sources of revenue generation for a Disney Corp. struggling so bad Bob Iger had to come out of retirement.

This article puts the April number at 50 million (https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/8/21214236/disney-plus-50-million-subscribers-international-europe-india-netflix), so it is very likely that an additional 5 million will be added before the end of lockdown.
Adjusting for India roll out after quarter end accounting for 8 million subscribers.
Disney+ Paid Subscriber Count Surpasses 50 Million - 4/8/20
Already over 50million subscribers, 5million more in 3 (or 4) weeks more likeley than not

Updating to reflect contents of press release. 
Diminished likelihood of not reporting given 1) structure of Q1 announcement; 2) isssuance of out-of-cycle press release; and 3) it's the major piece of good news for their stock price, they will want to draw as much attention to it as possible.

Misread and thought subscriber count until May matters. In Mid april 50mio of which 8 million were Indian with launch date 3rd of April. Thus basically all in 35 - 45 or no publication because other numbers way bigger.
A bit more pessimistic about growth in last month. No release coming and saturation might be reached.

Considerations:
		* 26.5mio is US only and pre corona
		* [Disney Plus surpasses 50 million subscribers in five months - CNET](https://www.cnet.com/news/disney-plus-surpasses-50-million-subscribers-in-five-months/) 
		* Covid will stay until May so asummably no big losses for now
I believe content matters, the service will see fast growth. But I presume that more than 100% growth in that time period is less likely, as infrastructure has to grow also.

its been reported that Disney accounts for 50 million Disney+ Sunscribers already. Since India accounts for 8 million and fiscal quarter ended March 31, the highest probability is assigned to the 35 million to 45 million category. However, the question remains are these numbers official are these all paid subscribers, since some are free subscriptions in connection with plans. The global app download with 17 million seems to also support higher probability to the 35-45 million range.

On the 8th of April, 5 months after launching, Disney announced 50 million Disney+ subscribers. 6 weeks after the launch, Disney+ had 26.5 million subscribers, 10 million of these were on the first day [1]. On the 24th of March, it launched in the UK, Ireland, Austria, Germany, Italy, Spain, and Switzerland. (Launch was delayed in France until April 7th) The launch in Europe probably followed a similar pattern to the US, especially due to the free 7-day trial. This means that the first week accounted for a much higher proportion of subscribers than the following weeks. Day one = 10 million
Week 6 = 26.5 million
Week 18 = European Launch
Week 19? = END OF Q2 FISCAL PERIOD
Week 20 = 50 million subscribers Between day 2 and week 6 there was an average increase of 0.402 million per day, 2.8 million per week. Assuming the growth in subscriber count diminished by around 40% per week and leveled off at 0.2 million, by week 18 there would be 5.27 million new subscribers, 31.77 million subscribers in total. +/- 3 million as 40% could be completely wrong. The European launch would have been a huge success due to the COVID-19 health crisis. There were 5 million Disney+ app downloads in the UK on the first day alone according to measurement and analytics firm ‘App Annie’. App downloads do not directly correlate with subscriber count (multiple accounts, TV and laptop viewers, etc ), but it does represent how big the launch was. By my guesstimations, Disney+ had between 28.77 and 34.77 million subscribers by week 18. Officially, they had 50 million by week 20. We know that roughly 8 million of these subscribers come from India[2]. It launched there on the 2nd of April, which is after Q2. The French launch also happened in April, one day before the 50 million subscriber’s announcement. Due to COVID-19 and the 7-day free trial, The European launch would have been very successful. I estimate between 6 and 9 million new subscribers in the first week. Furthermore, Trump ordered Americans to stay at home in late March. This would have increased the number of US subscribers per week. I estimate another 1 million subscribers in the last 2 weeks of March. 31.77 + 7.5 + 1 =  40.27 million. (between 35.77 and 44.77) However, it cannot be higher than "around" 42 million. India's launch was after March and accounted for "around" 8 million of the 50 million  Disney+ subscribers.   Criticism is very welcome! [1]https://wsiltv.com/2019/11/27/disney-plus-gets-10-million-subscribers-in-first-day/
[2] https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-plus-streaming-subscriber-count-growth-50-million-2020-4?r=US&IR=T
Families in lockdown all over Europe this is a good time to launch Disney+
Oh my .........I have read the question wrong so have therefore now altered my forcaste .........totally

Already reported to have surpassed 50 million after international expansion. https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/8/21214236/disney-plus-50-million-subscribers-international-europe-india-netflix Likely to continue to surge given covid-19 and cuts to Netflix streaming quality. Normal Netflix subscription increase is 5% / quarter or 1-2% per month so there is a chance Disney may not make 55 million using this base rate, but Netflix reported around 170 subscribers at the end of Q4 2019, so they're further along the growth curve. https://www.statista.com/statistics/250934/quarterly-number-of-netflix-streaming-subscribers-worldwide/

As of 8 April, had 50m subs.  But 8m were from India which launched 3 April.  So that suggests max 42m on 3 April.   Much of Europe cam on in late March so maybe 2 - 3m in first week of April that’s suggests about 39-40m in Q1.   With some risk that I missed launch dates late April.

I think that the Covid-19 outbreak will be positive for Disney with parents having to work from home and need a trusted content provider . I have also considered it possible that if the figures are poor it would be in the culture of Disney not to reveal the figures

Just rolled out in India last week.  There are a lot of people in India, but of course relatively few are Disney+ prospects.  However, a small percentage of a large number is a large number.  That said, Disney doesn't confide in me, so my number is pretty much just a guess.

Disney announced 50 million subscribers, but 8 million of them came from India, which won’t count towards 1Q20 numbers because Disney+ launched in India on 3 Apr. That means they should report at least 42 million subscribers in 1Q20.
Had about 28M subscribers in November and Disney continued with plans to launch internationally (https://www.cnet.com/news/disney-plus-everything-to-know-coronavirus-onward-pixar-artemis-fowl/).

As of Feb 23, the app has 28.6M (+1.1M since last FY).
The app was downloaded 16M times (including from Europe) last March and assuming that there's 65% unique downloads and 80% churn rate for subscribers, the estimated number of new subscribers for March be 8.32M. Giving the estimated total to 36.92M. I'm not 100% sure because there's a possibility that majority of the downloads were done during the last week of the month and were on trial period.

https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/02/disney-plus-india-launched-netflix-amazon-prime-video/ Disney+ is about to launch in India via Hostar. Reportedly Hostar has 1.5 mil subscribers. This increases the likelihood they will exceed 45 mil subscribers so I have amended my forecast accordingly.
I feel it will rise as people are staying in locked down with children or even adults like myself who would happily watch.

It seems unlikely that they will not experience significant growth during the first part of the social isolation period, especially with a very deep catalog of material and the relatively low price at a time when there are not as many other entertainment spending options.

Disney reported 26.5 million subscribers in Q1 2020 which, according to the CEO, increased to 28.6 million (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/04/disney-plus-subscriber-numbers-26point5-million.html). The service has since been released into some of the most populous European countries including the UK, Germany, Spain and Italy. It will be released in France soon. Since people are having to spend more time at home it follows that there will be an increase in the number of subscriptions.
New forecast based on the number of 5 Million downloads in western Europe at the first day of the disney plus launch.

Whilst not transcending into subscriptions it definitely appears that: 
It won’t break into the upper limits as the number isn’t big enough. 
And it should take the numbers clear of 35 million
A lot more people will subscribe while stuck indoors due to coronavirus, also the European launch will be huge.

Rough:
1) On Feb 3 it had 28.6m (from Q1 conf. call). This was +2.1m from end December.
2) From Antenna analytics chart (https://medium.com/antennaanalytics/the-impact-of-covid-19-disney-sign-ups-spike-d178456435eb) it had roughly same increment from Feb 3 to March 14th (+2.1m, cumulatively c.31m).
4) From March 14th onwards, Antenna estimate of virus = 2.6x uptick in daily signups vs. 2020 average. (Extrapolating adds c.2.2m in USA to month end, cumulatively c.33m)
5) Launch of 7 European countries on 24th. Assuming this is c.85% of Nov launch population & they are 75% as interested in Disney, that's +c.6.5m on day 1 (day 1 in Nov. was 10m). Cumulatively c.40m.
6) Assume incremental c.2.2m in Europe from launch to end Q2 (from Nov. launch daily run rate after first day). Cumulatively c.42m.

March 22, 2020: By the end of Diney's Q2 they will be available in 7 countries. Netflix has a subscription rate of ~20% in these countries. Disney+ currently has ~27M subscribers (7.4% in these countries). D+ is cheaper the NFLX and the at the break point of 35M (~10%) I believe that D+ will reach that but definitely won't go above 55M (~15.6%) subscribers. Verizon cross promotion offer may increase +/- 1M subscriptions but won't impact.

Delaying launch in UK. Slowing down speed in Europe. Not launching in India. About 30 million with 9 days to go. Probably no more than 10 to 20 million new subscribers. Also this: https://bgr.com/2020/02/26/disney-plus-vs-netflix-subscribers-declining/

Minor updates in numbers due to changing situation
- India and France launch delayed
- Perhaps more interest than expected in the EU due to lockdowns. Conversely there is lower streaming quality due to throttling but I don't expect that to affect subscriber numbers much.

Slight increase in the chances of a 45-55 due to the success of the platform following the Covid lockdowns. The U.K. also has a discounted offer which is appealing (it has made me subscribe for one).  https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/348789/disney-plus-subscriptions-soaring.html
I lowered the possibility for "Less than 35,0 million" because of the high demand for online services as the coronavirus crisi continues.

I have changed my prediction to a 63% possibility that Disney+ will have more than 55M paying customers by the end of 2Q20 due to a new announcement that was just released by Deadline that states that, "Up to 50% of U.S. internet users with children under 10 in their households have already subscribed to the Disney+ streaming service" [1]. According to Statista.com, there are approximately 18,414,550 families in the United States (as of 2019) that have at least one child under the age of 11 [2]. Further, the Deadline article states that "more than four in 10 (41%) of 18- to 24-year-olds say they already have access to the service" [1]. According to Marketingcharts.com, there are appx 30.5M individuals in this age group [3]. Additionally, Nielsen reports that TV usage spiked 60% during previous crisis' and there was an increase of 104% in TV watching by teenagers in Seattle [4]. Another factor to take into consideration is that Universal Pictures announced this week that they will release current theatrical releases to households via a "Video on Demand" package [5]. There have also been rumors that Disney might follow suit by releasing Black Widow on Disney+ [6]. To note, that source is from 4Chan, so I judge it to be highly unreliable, however, I am including it here because of Universal's actions. It is currently impacting my assessment by less than 1%. I will continue to monitor this prediction as I assess it will change again. Please point out/correct any incorrect statements/analysis/assessments I have made. [1] https://deadline.com/2020/03/half-of-us-families-young-children-subscribe-disney-report-1202885339/
[2] https://deadline.com/2020/03/half-of-us-families-young-children-subscribe-disney-report-1202885339/

[4] https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/17/nielsen-explains-how-covid-19-could-impact-media-usage-across-the-u-s/
[5] https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/16/media/universal-movies-streaming-coroanvirus/index.html
[6] https://boundingintocomics.com/2020/03/17/rumor-disney-thinking-about-releasing-scarlett-johanssons-black-widow-directly-to-disney-plus/

The Coronavirus will drive up the number of new subscribers. Dysney+ will soon be avaliable in more markets (UK for example)

Disney struck an agreement with Verizon to provide all current Verizon wireless customers with one free year of Disney+. Verizon Wireless has appx 118 million subscribers. If 10% of those customers join Disney+, that provides Disney an additional 11.8 million subscribers. They reported on 4 Feb that they already had 28.6 million subscribers so just adding a small amount of Verizon customers would push the number of total subscribers to 40.4 million subscribers. Further, Disney+ is expanding to the UK, Ireland, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Austria and Switzerland in March. If 15%of the paying Netflix customers in those countries subscribe to Disney+, that would be an additional 5.2M (appx). Using Netflix’s subscriber growth in 2019 as a model. We could anticipate a 1.6% paying customer growth per month for Disney+ which would put them at appx 30.1 million subscribers in the US alone (not including Verizon Wireless customers). This would put the conservative estimate of Disney+ subscribers at 30.1M + 11.8M + 5.2M = 47.1 Million subscribers. If there is a larger than predicted number of Verizon subscribers and/or international subscribers, and the COVID-19 country quarantine advances across Europe, I assess that there is a 45% chance that Disney+ could announce more than 55 million subscribers. However, since it is a new service with a limited library (compared to other streaming services) and a smaller amount of original programing, I assess there is a 55% probability that they will announce between 45M and 55M subscribers.
With coronovirus spread, people will look for more at home entertainment. The cost is minimal I do not forsee that beeing a deterent in light of the virus.
28 million now. Due to coronavirus people might not take on new expenses.

As of now the number is 28.6 million (1). It launched in US, Canada, Netherlands, Australia and New Zealand in Q1. Comparing with Netflix, which has roughly 90 million Netflix subscribers in those countries as of 2019 (2), Disney having roughly 1/3 of that number through Q1
Disney will Launch in the UK, Germany, Italy, Austria, Spain, France, Ireland and Switzerland in Q2. (3) The Netflix subscribers in those countries are roughly 36 million. (2). 
Streaming revenue in the US is roughly double that of Europe.  (4). Therefore i will take a conservative 6th of the Q2 netflix subscriptions (36 million) = 6 million. Factor in that subscriptions grew by 2 million since the Dec figures. So its likely they will increase again. Lets say the same amount.  28.6+6+2 = 36.6 million.  The other factor is the Verizon free yearly subscription, which according to the Q1 breakdown, this will meet the definition of a paying subscription and will be included. The question is how many of the 17 million Verizon  users eligible (5) will activate their subscription. 
I believe that is the key factor in this question. If all 17 million sign up then i would estimate 53 million. This is unlikely, only 8% of Dutch households took the offer of a free trial during Q1. At 50% uptake i would estimate 44.5 million. As this is on the border of the estimate, but ambitious at 50% uptake. The figure is more likely to be less than 44.5 than more. 
Around 42 million can be expected  Disney would likely publish their findings as they did in Q1 (1) https://techcrunch.com/2020/02/04/disney-plus-subscribers/
(2) https://www.comparitech.com/tv-streaming/netflix-subscribers/
(3) https://www.techradar.com/news/disney-plus-shows-movies-sign-up
(4) https://www.statista.com/outlook/206/102/video-streaming--svod-/europe)
(5) https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/03/08/disney-using-netflix-strategy-reach-millions-fast.aspx

Subscriber growth beat expectations in Q1.  Further growth in Q2 will include international expansion (harder to accomplish and more costly).  Disney mgt is transitioning but subscriber growth seems to be expected since commentary is for subscriber income to compensate for potential park closings due to Coronavirus.  Growth unlikely to beat Q1 but also less likely to fail badly - which will be suggested by a NR of Q2 subscriber growth.
Considering their current standing the might exceed 35ml

At their current growth rates, i expect 31-33 million 'paying' subscriber figures for Disney+ in the US, but the launching in Europe in late March may bring in 2-4 million new subscribers in the first week. That put the figure at 33-37 million which is just finely balanced.

Disney+ had 26.5 million subscribers at December 28th 2019. Bob Iger reported that they had 28.6 million on February 3rd 2020 - a 2.1 million growth for the month of January. Assuming a similiar growth for February and March (when their 2nd quarter ends), would suggest around 33 million US subscribers.  They are launching in Europe on 24th of March in 8 countries: UK, Ireland, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Austria and Switzerland. The total population of these countries is around 345 million people - a comparable number to the 327 million in the US. However, Netflix subscribers in the chosen countries are around half as many as in the US (around 28-29 million to 58 million). Therefore, it seems impossible for Disney to gain the 11 millions subscribers in their first week to beat the 45 million benchmark. Furthermore, Disney does not seem to be releasing as important of a show as the Mandalorian for their Europran launch. Leaving a small percentage chance of a complete flop on the European market (less than 1 to 2 million in the first week) and small chance of not reporting the figures (extremelly unlikely as they moved their European launch date from 31st to 24th of March, likely just for reporting purposes).

Disney have already reported on their first quarter results so no reason to assume they won't report on second quarter hence the low percentage for the final option.
They have already reported 26.5 million on it's first quarter in the US and the CEO has provided an update that the number is up to 28.6million on Feb 3rd.
Verizon have been offering free Disney access to new and existing customers (which disney will count as paying -20% of disney subscribers are from verizon but 17million will be eligible according to verizon ceo).
Netflix reported 167million subscribers at the end of Q4 so a conservative estimate of 15% of users willing to pay for double services makes 25million additional.
Europe launching at promotional offer of £49.99 makes it highly attractive to encourage early sign ups.

Growth in the U.S. is likely to slow, but the expansion into Europe in March should put it over the 35.0 million mark.  Overall, I would expect to see an increase in subscription services over the next quarter as people limit social activities dues to COVID-19 fears.

Existing markets (UCAN+Oceania): grew ~2.1mil in Jan 2020. Assuming same growth, +4mil by Mar 2020.
- Assumption: nCov boost + slowing subscriber growth in existing markets should cancel out. Upcoming limited EU rollout (Mar 24): based on Netflix regional subscriber comparisons, expecting this number to be between 40-50% of UCAN numbers.
Expected UCAN (Mar 2020): 28.6+4 = 32.6.
Expected total EU interest (Mar 2020): 32.6*0.45 = 14.67mil
Expected growth: UCAN got 10mil in 1st day + average 2.5mil every week until Dec 2019.
Based on 1 week rollout, despite nearly 15mil interest, only 0.45*(12.5) ~ 5.65mil subscribers by end Mar. APAC: Huge uncertainty due to India launch planned Mar 29. Based on premium Hotstar subscribers, 3% of 75mil ~ 2.25mil boost. Assuming some time taken in the rollout, expecting +1mil. Total expected = 28.6+4+5.65+1 = 39.25.

Netflix has around 40-50 million subscriptions in Europe. So lets say (zipfs law) 20% of them are willing to wither double purchase or leave a subscription service. So 8-9 million people up for grabs. Add that to the 29 million (Im adding lag to the 26.5) and we are looking at 37-38 million. So already we can see that an optimistic outlook places it above the 35 mark.  Then we should ask about obstacles. How likely are people to get into Disney at this point in time? Well - only 393,000 disney life subscribers move over - its difficult to get access through smart TVs, people haven't formed the habit yet ... and subscriptions can be divided up. All in this creates a downward pull on the numbers.  Pulling up, it will be families that want it - and family money matters. Europe being a big market ...

The first quarter was about 29 million... Netflix raised it subscription fee whereas Disney+ has a low introductory fee so more will switch from Netflix to Disney+ as families find more varied content on Disney+

A Feb 3 report showed Disney+ at 28.6 mil putting growth at 2.1 million in a month. Netflix was at 62 mil (167 wordwide) and Hulu at 30.4. The service is set to launch in UK, Ireland, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Austria, and Switzerland on March 24 with further launches in Western Europe markets, including Belgium, the Nordics, and Portugal, following in summer 2020. This is not all of Europe. Video streaming revenue in Europe is roughly half of the US (https://www.statista.com/outlook/206/102/video-streaming--svod-/europe). If the rate remains the same, that would yield an additional 14 mil subscribers (assuming a two month ramp is sufficient). Need to consider the lack of Belgium, the nordics, and Portugal. However, "at home" services may receive a boost from the coronavirus. Putting it all together, I see a growth between 16-20 million additional users in Q1
Netflix has 150mln, Amazon 40mln, but Disney has much lower choice, marketing expenses etc, plus they had only 2mln growth per q

Factors.  Intl. launch delay risk vs COVID tail wind/head wind.   My Point estimate is 39m.   28.6m as of Feb 3.  Vs 26.5m at Dec 31.  So 2m net adds without extra launches.   —> 30m at end of Q without new launches.   Uk, france, Germany, Italy, Spain  (pion approx 250m) are launching due March 24 - so about 7 days for those new countries.  This puts it on the 33m to 42m type of range, but could have single demand.  Plus India supposedly launches on March 29 (?!)  so there is launch day in India to consider.  I’m making a 39m point estimate without over thinking.

Watching this one to fall into context as the VIRUS consumes consumer spending. My thinking is that Staycations  may bee a boon to domestic tourism - OR - EVERYONE HOLES UP FOR THE DURATION AND SUBSCRIBER SERVICES FLOURISH.
